course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Medical Imaging
course.description: This course introduces medical imaging methods to senior undergraduate and graduate students.  It covers the following topics: radiation, radiography, computer tomography, radioisotope imaging, diagnostic ultrasound imaging, magnetic resonance imaging, and applications of different imaging modalities.  This course requires basic knowledge of linear algebra, calculus, and geometry.  Familiarity with a programming language such as MATLAB is needed.
course.prerequisites: ELEC 2100 AND MATH 2011 AND MATH 2111

reviews.author: Bill_
reviews.title: Pay attention to the discussion questions
reviews.comment_content:
1. Basic principles of medical imaging modalities
- Background of geometry, linear algebra, calculus, signals and
systems, F.T.,...
- X-ray projection imaging
- Computed tomography
- Emission tomography: SPECT and PET
- Ultrasound imaging
- Magnetic resonance imaging
2. Some application examples
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor and TAs are very nice. The problem is only a small portion of the material is covered in class.

ELEC 4820 adopts "blended learning style", which means:
- You need to study the course material beforehand.
- Only one class per week, which focuses on the discussion instead of teaching.

The learning material is not easy and I think many students get lost when they learn on their own.
reviews.comment_grading:
10%: Homework
10%: Online quiz
10%: Attendance and discussion participation
30%: Mid-term
40%: Final exam

Answering discussion questions in class will earn you bonus points.

As for myself:
Homework gets full marks
Both midterm and final 90+
Very few bonus points.
The final grade is A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light.
4-5 discussion questions every week but not compulsory. You can get some bonus points if you email the solution to the professor/TA before the class. They are quite important when you are preparing for exams.
1 easy quiz per week.
Several assignments throughout the semester. Many questions are from the top reference book.

reviews.comment_teaching:
This course adopts blended learning mode. While there are lectures on Mondays and Fridays according to schedule, there are no classes on Monday, as you are expected to learn everything about this course on your own through the materials (e.g. slides, videos, etc) provided on Canvas.

While the professor as well as the TA are very nice in helping us clear up any difficult concepts, I find a lot of fellow students, myself included, often become lost during class. I also don't think blended learning is an efficient way for students to truly remember what they've learnt in courses.

Attendance for Friday lectures is compulsory. The professor doesn't like students who are late for classes, so you might want to be punctual.
reviews.comment_workload:
Materials will be posted on a weekly basis, along with a brief learning guide that would give you the order to read each material. After that, you need to complete a short MC quiz on Canvas within the week. The quizzes consists of 5 questions, and basically revises the key concepts and theories you have learnt from the slides and videos provided.

You'll also need to complete a series of discussion questions to be discussed on Friday lectures. Although the discussion questions are unnecessary and do not count anything towards the final grade, volunteering and trying them out in lectures can give you bonus marks in participation.

Each student is expected to solve at least 1 - 2 discussion problems throughout the entire course. If nobody can solve a certain problem, it will be added as part of the upcoming homework.

Both midterm and final exams are open-book, with questions very similar to homework assignments. You can bring any materials you need for the exam, including the textbook. The professor specified only "traditional" calculators (no programmable or scientific calculators) were allowed. This can work for midterm problems, but for final term you'll need a scientific calculators to solve certain problems such as Bohr's Equation. Bringing a scientific calculator is still highly recommended, because TA allows it. In addition, studying the problems from all editions of the textbook, as well as discussion and exam materials from past semesters, would also aid you in revising the exam.

reviews.author: AY
reviews.comment_content:
This course introduces medical imaging methods to senior undergraduate and graduate students.  It covers the following topics:  radiation, radiography, computer tomography, radioisotope imaging, diagnostic ultrasound imaging, magnetic resonance imaging, and applications of different imaging modalities.

The topic is really interesting. You will learn a lot about medical imaging if you want to do the similar work for your career.

This course is not usually opened. I am lucky that I can take it in this year. It may not appear in the next fall semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is kind and always gave bonus points in the lecture. But he is not good at teaching. The lecture is very boring. You can just skip all the lectures and watch the online videos. Most of the material you need to read it by yourself. Do not hesitating to spend your time to read them. They are interesting and meaningful. The only bad point is the professor tone........

Midterm and Final exam are open book. The question are similar to the assignment. Therefore, you have to do the assignment by yourself for your preparation.

reviews.author: elessar
reviews.title: Hard Lecture, Easy Homework and Easy grade
reviews.comment_content:
The content is quite nicely designed, which gives an overview of how each of the following medical imaging systems works:
1. X-Ray
2. CT
3. Nuclear Medicine Imaging
4. Ultrasound Imaging
5. MRI
The course focuses on the theoretical reasoning behind the technique and delves into the math part, though not too deep. And the professor will go through every bit of the math with the students.

For the first two chapters, those who have not learned (understand the essence of) Fourier Transform or has not taken Signal Processing Course BEWARE! It will be a nightmare.

And you do not have to be familiar with any programming language...
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Yu is very knowledgeable in this field and very passionate. But it does not seem that he could teach very well. He talks slowly with substandard English. To truly understand the course material, one has to think and reason by oneself. Make a conjecture about what Professor means and then ask him about whether one's conjecture is true is the most efficient way to learn from Professor Yu.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is extremely good. Absolute grading.
And one does not need to understand the lecture to achieve good grades. As long as you could fully understand the tutorial slides, which is basically simple physics, you are fine with the grade. For this semester, there are 16 people in the class and for the final, there are seven to eight students who score more than 95. Absolute Grading, ta da~
So I kind of think for our semester, half of the students get an A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light homework. Five homework corresponding to five major imaging techniques. If you understand the tutorial, (mind you, the tutorial is way much easier than lecture), then you could do homework and achieve good grades in both midterm and final.
